a.g: [All] praise is [due] to Allah, who has sent down upon His Servant the Book and has not made therein any deviance.
[He has made it] straight, to warn of severe punishment from Him and to give good tidings to the believers who do righteous deeds that they will have a good reward
In which they will remain forever
And to warn those who say, "Allah has taken a son."
They have no knowledge of it, nor had their fathers. Grave is the word that comes out of their mouths; they speak not except a lie.
Then perhaps you would kill yourself through grief over them, [O Muhammad], if they do not believe in this message, [and] out of sorrow.
Indeed, We have made that which is on the earth adornment for it that We may test them [as to] which of them is best in deed.

ğŸ“– Vol 1: Arrangement of Litanies
For these people, all their states (ahwal) become suitable to be a cause for their increase, so no worship (ibadah) is distinguished from another worship for them. They are the ones who fled to Allah (Allah) the Exalted in Might, as He said: 'That you may remember' (Quran 18:24). So they fled to Allah, and His saying is realized in them: 'And when you withdraw from them and that which they worship except Allah, then take refuge in the cave; your Lord will spread for you of His mercy (rahmah) and will prepare for you from your affair a comfort (mirfaq)' (Quran 18:16). And to this is the indication by His saying: 'Indeed, I am going to my Lord; He will guide me' (Quran 37:99). And this is the utmost degrees of the truthful ones (siddiqin), and there is no reaching it except after arranging the litanies (awrad) and persisting in them for a long time. So it is not appropriate for the seeker (murid) to be deceived by what he heard of that and claim it for himself and become negligent in the duties of his worship. Its sign is that no whisper (waswas) stirs in his heart (qalb), nor does a sin (ma'siyah) occur to his heart, nor do the assaults of terrors (hawal) alarm him, nor do the great affairs (ashghal) agitate him. And how is this rank (rutbah) granted to everyone? So it is incumbent upon all to arrange the litanies as we have mentioned.

So then, how can one argue for seclusion from the disbelievers and idols to justify seclusion from the Muslims, given the abundance of blessing (Barakah) among them? a.g: And [had you been present], you would see the sun when it rose, inclining away from their cave on the right, and when it set, passing away from them on the left, while they were [laying] within an open space thereof. That was from the signs of Allah. He whom Allah guides is the [rightly] guided, but he whom He leaves astray - never will you find for him a protecting guide.

And you would think them awake, while they were asleep. And We turned them to the right and to the left, while their dog stretched his forelegs at the entrance. If you had looked at them, you would have turned from them in flight and been filled by them with terror.

And similarly, We awakened them that they might question one another. Said a speaker from among them, "How long have you remained [here]?" They said, "We have remained a day or part of a day." They said, "Your Lord is most knowing of how long you remained. So send one of you with this silver coin of yours to the city and let him look to which is the best of food and bring you provision from it and let him be cautious. And let no one be aware of you.
Indeed, if they come to know of you, they will stone you or return you to their religion. And never would you succeed, then - ever."

And similarly, We caused them to be found that they [who found them] would know that the promise of Allah is truth and that of the Hour there is no doubt. [That was] when they disputed among themselves about their affair and [then] said, "Construct over them a structure. Their Lord is most knowing about them." Said those who prevailed in the matter, "We will surely take [for ourselves] over them a masjid."

They will say there were three, the fourth of them being their dog; and they will say there were five, the sixth of them being their dog - guessing at the unseen; and they will say there were seven, and the eighth of them was their dog. Say, [O Muhammad], "My Lord is most knowing of their number. None knows them except a few. So do not argue about them except with an obvious argument and do not inquire about them among [the speculators] from anyone."
And never say of anything, "Indeed, I will do that tomorrow,"

ğŸ“– Vol 1: Foundations of Belief
The second aspect: The etiquette of mentioning Allah (God) the Exalted in every state and referring all matters to the will of Allah (God) the Glorified. Indeed, Allah (God) the Glorified taught etiquette to His Prophet (peace be upon him) when He the Exalted said: 'And never say of anything, "Indeed, I will do that tomorrow," except [when adding], "If Allah (God) wills."' Then He did not restrict that to matters about which there is no doubt, but rather said: 'You will surely enter the Sacred Mosque, if Allah (God) wills, in safety, with your heads shaved and [hair] shortened.' And Allah (God) the Glorified was knowing that they would enter inevitably and that He willed it, but the intended purpose was teaching him that. So the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) observed etiquette in what he would inform about, whether it was known or doubtful, until he (peace be upon him) said when he entered the graveyards: 'Peace be upon you, O abode of believing people, and we, if Allah (God) wills, will be joining you.' And joining them is not a matter of doubt, but the requirement of etiquette is mentioning Allah (God) the Exalted and linking matters to Him. And this formulation indicates that, until it became, by customary usage, an expression for showing desire and wish. So if it is said to you that so-and-so will die quickly, and you say 'If Allah (God) wills,' it is understood from it your desire, not your doubt. And if it is said to you that so-and-so's illness will depart and he will recover, and you say 'If Allah (God) wills' with the meaning of desire, then the word has shifted from the meaning of doubt to the meaning of desire, and likewise the shift to the meaning of etiquette for mentioning Allah (God) the Exalted, however the matter may be.

a.g: Except [when adding], "If Allah wills." And remember your Lord when you forget [it] and say, "Perhaps my Lord will guide me to what is nearer than this to right conduct."
And they remained in their cave for three hundred years and exceeded by nine.

Say, "Allah is most knowing of how long they remained. He has [knowledge of] the unseen [aspects] of the heavens and the earth. How Seeing is He and how Hearing! They have not besides Him any protector, and He shares not His legislation with anyone."
And recite, [O Muhammad], what has been revealed to you of the Book of your Lord. There is no changer of His words, and never will you find in other than Him a refuge.

And keep yourself patient [by being] with those who call upon their Lord in the morning and the evening, seeking His countenance. And let not your eyes pass beyond them, desiring adornments of the worldly life, and do not obey one whose heart We have made heedless of Our remembrance and who follows his desire and whose affair is ever [in] neglect.

ğŸ“– Vol 4: Poverty and Abstinence
[23] A hadith: The chiefs and wealthy of the Arabs said to the Prophet (peace be upon him): 'Appoint a day for us and a day for them.' The hadith concerns the revelation of His saying, the Exalted: 'And restrain your Soul (Nafs) with those who call upon their Lord in the morning and the evening, desiring His Face, and let not your eyes pass beyond them, desiring the adornment of the worldly life. And one of them would be offered lawful wealth but would not take it, saying: 'I fear it will corrupt my Heart (Qalb).' So whoever has a Heart (Qalb) inevitably fears its corruption. And those whose Hearts (Qalb) have been killed by the love of the worldly life, Allah has informed about them when He said, the Exalted: 'And they are content with the worldly life and feel secure with it, and those who are heedless of Our signs.' And He, the Mighty and Majestic, said: 'And do not obey one whose Heart (Qalb) We have made heedless of Our Remembrance (Dhikr) and who follows his own desire (Hawa) and whose affair is ever [in] neglect.' And He, the Exalted, said: 'So turn away from whoever turns away from Our Remembrance (Dhikr) and desires not except the worldly life. That is their extent of knowledge.' So He attributed all of that to heedlessness (Ghafala) and lack of knowledge, and for that reason a man said to Jesus, peace be upon him: 'Take me with you in your journeying.' He said: 'Bring out your wealth and follow me.' He said: 'I am not able.' So Jesus, peace be upon him, said: 'It is amazing that a rich man enters Paradise' - or he said: 'with difficulty.'

The seventh: Pride (Al-'Ujb) in wealth, as Allah the Exalted said, reporting about the owner of the two gardens when he said: "I am more than you in wealth and mightier in supporters (Nafar)." And the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) saw a wealthy man sitting next to a poor man, so he withdrew from him and gathered his garments. The Prophet (peace be upon him) said: "Did you fear that his poverty (Fa-qr) would leap onto you?" That was due to pride in wealth. Its remedy is to reflect on the harms of wealth, the multitude of its obligations, and the greatness of its dangers, and to look at the virtue of the poor and their precedence to Paradise on the Day of Resurrection (Al-QiyÄmah), and that wealth comes and goes and has no foundation, and that among the Jews there are those who exceed him in wealth, and to his saying (peace be upon him): "While a man was strutting in a garment that had impressed his Soul (Nafs), Allah commanded the earth, and it seized him, and he is sinking in it until the Day of Resurrection (Al-QiyÄmah)." And he indicated by this the punishment for his pride in his wealth and his Soul (Nafs).

ğŸ“– Vol 3: Condemnation of Pride and Conceit
Fifth: Arrogance (Kibr) through wealth; this occurs among kings regarding their treasuries, among merchants regarding their goods, among landowners regarding their lands, and among those who adorn themselves regarding their clothing, horses, and vehicles. The rich person belittles the poor person and acts arrogantly toward him, saying: You are destitute and poor, and if I wanted, I could buy someone like you and employ someone superior to you. Who are you? What do you have? The furnishings of my house are worth more than all your wealth? I spend in one day what you do not eat in a year? All of this is due to his magnifying of wealth and belittling of poverty, and all of this is ignorance on his part regarding the virtue (Fadilah) of poverty and the affliction (Afah) of wealth. To this is the allusion in His saying, the Exalted: 'And he had fruit, so he said to his companion while conversing with him: I am more than you in wealth and mightier in followers (Nafar)' until he answered him, saying: 'If you see me less than you in wealth and children, then perhaps my Lord will give me better than your garden and send upon it a reckoning from the sky, so it becomes a slippery bare plain, or its water becomes sunken, then you will never be able to seek it.' And that was from him arrogance (Takabbur) through wealth and children. Then Allah made clear the consequence of his matter with His saying: 'Oh, would that I had not associated with my Lord anyone.' And from that is the arrogance (Takabbur) of Qarun when Allah said, informing about his arrogance (Takabbur): 'So he went out to his people in his adornment. Those who desired the worldly life said: Oh, would that we had the like of what was given to Qarun. Indeed, he is one of great fortune.'

ğŸ“– Vol 1: Invocations and Supplications
If you say: Why is the Remembrance (Dhikr) of Allah, the Exalted, despite its lightness on the tongue and the little exertion in it, become better and more beneficial than the entirety of acts of worship with their many hardships in them? Then know that the realization of this is not fitting except with the knowledge of unveiling (Mukashafa) and the measure that permits mentioning it in the science of interaction (Mu'amala) that the effective, beneficial thing is the Remembrance (Dhikr) perpetually with the presence of the Heart (Qalb). As for the Remembrance (Dhikr) with the tongue while the Heart (Qalb) is heedless, it is of little benefit, and in the reports there is also what indicates this. And the presence of the Heart (Qalb) in a moment with the Remembrance (Dhikr) and the distraction from Allah, the Mighty and Majestic, while being occupied with the worldly life is also of little benefit. Rather, the presence of the Heart (Qalb) with Allah, the Exalted, perpetually or in most times is what is given precedence over acts of worship. Indeed, by it all other acts of worship are ennobled, and it is the ultimate fruit of practical acts of worship. And the Remembrance (Dhikr) has a beginning and an end. Its beginning necessitates intimacy and love for Allah, and its end necessitates intimacy and love and issues from it, and what is sought is that intimacy and love. For the seeker (Murid) at the beginning of his affair may be constrained in diverting his Heart (Qalb) and tongue from the whisperings to the Remembrance (Dhikr) of Allah, the Mighty and Majestic. ğŸ“– Vol 3: Condemnation of Pride and Conceit
Fifth: Arrogance (Kibr) through wealth; this occurs among kings regarding their treasuries, among merchants regarding their goods, among landowners regarding their lands, and among those who adorn themselves regarding their clothing, horses, and vehicles. Thus, the rich person despises the poor person and acts arrogantly toward him, saying: You are a pauper and destitute, and if I wished, I could buy someone like you and employ someone superior to you. Who are you? What do you possess, and the furnishings of my house are worth more than all your wealth? I spend in one day what you do not eat in a year? All of that is due to his magnifying of wealth and his belittling of poverty, and all of that is ignorance on his part regarding the virtue of poverty and the affliction of wealth. To this, the indication is in His saying, the Exalted: 'He said to his companion while conversing with him: I am more than you in wealth and mightier in men' until he answered him, saying: 'If you see me as less than you in wealth and children, then perhaps my Lord will give me better than your garden and send upon it a reckoning from the sky, so it becomes a slippery bare plain or its water becomes deep-sunken, then you will never be able to seek it.' And that was from him arrogance through wealth and children. Then Allah made clear the outcome of his affair with His saying: 'Oh, would that I had not associated with my Lord anyone.' And from that is the arrogance of Qarun when Allah said, informing about his arrogance: 'So he went out to his people in his adornment. Those who desired the worldly life said: Oh, would that we had the like of what was given to Qarun. Indeed, he is one of great fortune.'

And the meaning of asceticism (Zuhd) is that the servant (Abd) masters his desire (Shahwa) and his anger (Ghadab), so they submit to the motivator of the religion (Din) and the indication of faith (Iman). And this is a kingdom by merit, for by it its possessor becomes free, and by the domination of desire (Shahwa) over him, he becomes a slave (Abd) to his private parts (Farj) and his stomach (Batin) and his other purposes, so he becomes harnessed like a beast, owned, pulled by the reins of desire (Shahwa), taken by its throat to where it wants and desires. So how great is the deception of the human being when he thought that he attains kingdom by becoming owned and attains lordship (Rububiyya) by becoming a slave (Abd). And such as this, can it be except inverted in the worldly life, overturned in the Hereafter?

ğŸ“– Vol 3: Condemnation of Status and Ostentation
Look how the ignorant have turned and fallen on their faces like the falling of the blind, so they turned to seeking perfection of power through status and wealth, which is a perfection that does not remain safe, and even if it remains safe, it has no permanence, and they turned away from the perfection of freedom and knowledge which, when attained, becomes eternal with no cessation. These are the ones who have purchased the worldly life in exchange for the Hereafter, so it is no wonder that the punishment is not lightened for them, nor are they helped. They are the ones who did not understand His saying, the Exalted: 'Wealth and children are the adornment of the worldly life, and the enduring righteous deeds are better with your Lord for reward and better for hope.' So knowledge and freedom are the enduring righteous deeds that remain as perfection in the soul (Nafs), and wealth and status are what perish in proximity, as Allah, the Exalted, has likened it where He said: 'The example of worldly life is like water which We send down from the sky...' the verse. And He, the Exalted, said: 'And present to them the example of the worldly life as water which We send down from the sky...' up to His saying: '...and it becomes dry debris scattered by the winds.' And everything that the winds of death scatter is the flower of the worldly life, and everything that death does not cut off is the enduring righteous deeds.

ğŸ“– Vol 4: Remembrance of Death and the Afterlife
And the creatures have raised their gazes to you, so imagine yourself that you are in the hands of those entrusted with you in this state until you reached the Throne of the Most Merciful, and they threw you from their hands, and Allah, Glorified and Exalted, called you with His mighty speech: 'O son of Adam, draw near to Me.' So you drew near to Him with a fluttering, sorrowful, fearful heart (Qalb), and a humble, submissive gaze, and a broken inner self (Fu'ad), and you were given your book which does not leave a small or a large [sin] except that it has enumerated it. How many obscenities you had forgotten, then you remembered them, and how many acts of obedience you were heedless of their defects, then their faults were unveiled to you. How much shame and cowardice you have, and how much confinement and incapacity you have. I wish I knew with which foot you stand before Him, and with which tongue you answer, and with which heart (Qalb) you comprehend what you say.

ğŸ“– Vol 3: Condemnation of Pride and Conceit
His Heart (Qalb) is severed in terror from the horror of this address before the scroll is spread open and he witnesses what is in it of his disgraceful acts. So when he witnesses it, he says, "Woe to us! What is with this book? It does not leave out a small thing nor a large thing except that it has enumerated it." This is his final affair, and it is the meaning of His saying, the Exalted, "Then when He wills, He will resurrect him." So what is for one in this state and arrogance and self-aggrandizement? Rather, what is for him and joy in a single moment, let alone insolence and extravagance? Indeed, his beginning state and middle have become apparent to him, and if his end were to appearâ€”and refuge is sought with Allah, the Exaltedâ€”perhaps he would choose to be a dog or a pig to become with the animals as dust and not be a human who hears an address or meets punishment. And if he is, with Allah, deserving of the Fire, then the pig is more noble than him and more pleasant and higher, since its beginning is dust and its end is dust, and it is removed from the Reckoning (Hisab) and the Punishment (Adhab), and the dog and the pig, the creation does not flee from them.

ğŸ“– Vol 3: Condemnation of Anger and Envy
The Narrations: Some of the predecessors said: The first sin is envy (Hasad) - Iblis envied Adam, peace be upon him, regarding his rank, so he refused to prostrate to him, and it carried him into envy (Hasad) and disobedience. And it is narrated that 'Awn ibn 'Abd Allah entered upon al-Fadl ibn al-Muhallab, who was then in Wasit, and said: I want to advise you with something. He said: And what is it? He said: Beware of arrogance (Kibr), for it is the first sin by which Allah was disobeyed, then he recited: "And [mention] when We said to the angels, 'Prostrate to Adam,' and they prostrated, except for Iblis. He was of the jinn and departed from the command of his Lord. Then will you take him and his descendants as allies other than Me while they are enemies to you? Wretched it is for the wrongdoers as an exchange.'" And beware of greed (Hirs), for it expelled Adam from Paradise - Allah, glorified be He, had enabled him in a garden the width of the heavens and the earth, he could eat from it except for one tree which He forbade him from, so he ate from it and Allah, exalted be He, expelled him from it, then he recited: "Descend from it" to the end of the verse. And beware of envy (Hasad), for indeed the son of Adam killed his brother when he envied him, then he recited: "And recite to them the story of Adam's two sons in truth," the verses. And when the companions of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, are mentioned, then refrain, and when predestination (Qadar) is mentioned, then be silent, and when the stars are mentioned, then be silent.

ğŸ“– Vol 1: Arrangement of Litanies
And from Ali, may God be pleased with him, that the Prophet, peace be upon him, came upon him and Fatima, may God be pleased with them both, while they were sleeping and said: 'Do you not pray?' Ali said: I said, O Messenger of God, indeed our souls (Nafs) are in the hand of God Almighty, so if He wills to send them forth, He sends them forth. Then the Prophet, peace be upon him, turned away, and I heard him as he was turning away striking his thigh and saying: 'And man is the most contentious of things (Quran 18:54).' [9] Then one should occupy oneself after the two rak'ahs of Fajr and its supplication with seeking forgiveness (Istighfar) and glorification (Tasbih) until the prayer is established, saying: 'I seek forgiveness from God, there is no god but He, the Living, the Self-Subsisting, and I repent to Him' seventy times, and 'Glory be to God, and praise be to God, and there is no god but God, and God is the Greatest' one hundred times, then pray the obligatory prayer, observing all that we have mentioned of the inner (Batin) and outer (Zahir) etiquettes in prayer and following the example (Qudwah). When finished with it, he sits in the mosque until sunrise in the remembrance (Dhikr) of God Almighty as we will arrange it, for he, peace be upon him, said: 'That I sit in my gathering remembering God Almighty in it from the morning prayer until sunrise is more beloved to me than freeing four slaves.' [10] And it is narrated that he, peace be upon him, when he prayed the morning prayer, would sit in his prayer place until the sun rises, and in some narrations, and pray two rak'ahs [11], meaning after the rising. And there has come regarding the virtue of that what cannot be enumerated.

a.g: And nothing has prevented the people from believing when guidance came to them and from asking forgiveness of their Lord except that there [must] befall them the [accustomed] precedent of the former peoples or that the punishment should come [directly] before them.

And We send not the messengers except as bringers of good tidings and warners. And those who disbelieve dispute by [using] falsehood to [attempt to] invalidate thereby the truth and have taken My verses, and that of which they are warned, in ridicule.

And who is more unjust than one who is reminded of the verses of his Lord but turns away from them and forgets what his hands have put forth? Indeed, We have placed over their hearts coverings, lest they understand it, and in their ears deafness. And if you invite them to guidance - they will never be guided, then - ever.

And your Lord is the Forgiving, full of mercy. If He were to impose blame upon them for what they earned, He would have hastened for them the punishment. Rather, for them is an appointment from which they will never find an escape.
And those cities - We destroyed them when they wronged, and We made for their destruction an appointed time.
And [mention] when Moses said to his servant, "I will not cease [traveling] until I reach the junction of the two seas or continue for a long period."
But when they reached the junction between them, they forgot their fish, and it took its course into the sea, slipping away.
So when they had passed beyond it, [Moses] said to his boy, "Bring us our morning meal. We have certainly suffered in this, our journey, [much] fatigue."

He said, "Did you see when we retired to the rock? Indeed, I forgot [there] the fish. And none made me forget it except Satan - that I should mention it. And it took its course into the sea amazingly".
[Moses] said, "That is what we were seeking." So they returned, following their footprints.
And they found a servant from among Our servants to whom we had given mercy from us and had taught him from Us a [certain] knowledge.

ğŸ“– Vol 3: Wonders of the Heart
And Abu Yazid and others used to say: 'The knowledgeable one (Alim) is not he who memorizes from a book, for if he forgets what he has memorized, he becomes ignorant. Rather, the knowledgeable one is he who takes his knowledge from his Lord (Rabb) at any time he wishes, without memorization or study.' And this is the divine knowledge (Ilm Rabbani). And to this is the allusion in His saying, the Exalted: 'And We taught him from Our presence knowledge (Wa 'Allamnahu min ladunna 'ilma)' - although all knowledge is from His presence, but some of it comes through intermediaries of teaching the creation, so that is not called 'presence knowledge' (Ilm Laduni). Rather, the 'presence' one is that which opens up in the secret (Sirr) of the heart (Qalb) without any customary cause from outside. These are the evidences from transmission, and if all that has come regarding it from verses, reports, and traditions were gathered, it would exceed enumeration. As for witnessing that through experiences, that also exceeds enumeration, and it appeared upon the Companions (Sahaba), the Successors (Tabi'in), and those after them.

ğŸ“– Vol 1: Book of Knowledge
And whenever the teacher indicates a path in learning, let the student follow it and abandon his own opinion, for the error of his guide is more beneficial to him than his own correctness in himself, since experience reveals subtleties whose hearing causes astonishment, while their benefit is great. How many a feverish patient is treated by the physician at some times with heat to increase his strength to a limit where he can bear the shock of treatment, and one who has no experience with this is amazed by it. And Allah the Exalted has alerted [us] with the story of Al-Khidr and Musa, peace be upon them both, where Al-Khidr said: 'Indeed, you will not be able to have patience (Sabr) with me. And how can you have patience (Sabr) over that of which you have not been given knowledge?' (Al-Kahf: 67-68). Then he stipulated upon him silence and submission (Taslim), saying: 'So if you follow me, then do not ask me about anything until I mention to you its remembrance (Dhikr).' (Al-Kahf: 70). Then he did not have patience (Sabr) and did not cease in his persistence until that became the cause of separation between them. And in summary, every student who retains for himself an opinion and choice (Ikhtiyar) apart from the choice (Ikhtiyar) of the teacher, judge him to be in failure and loss.

a.g: As for the ship, it belonged to poor people working at sea. So I intended to cause defect in it as there was after them a king who seized every [good] ship by force.
And as for the boy, his parents were believers, and we feared that he would overburden them by transgression and disbelief.
So we intended that their Lord should substitute for them one better than him in purity and nearer to mercy.

And as for the wall, it belonged to two orphan boys in the city, and there was beneath it a treasure for them, and their father had been righteous. So your Lord intended that they reach maturity and extract their treasure, as a mercy from your Lord. And I did it not of my own accord. That is the interpretation of that about which you could not have patience."

ğŸ“– Vol 3: Condemnation of Miserliness
Know that Allah the Exalted has called wealth good in places of His Noble Book, so say He is Glorified and Exalted: "If he leaves good" the verse, and the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: "How excellent is righteous wealth for a righteous man"[13], and all that comes regarding the reward of charity and pilgrimage is praise of wealth since it is not possible to reach them except through it. And He the Exalted said: "And they extract their treasure as a mercy from your Lord" and He the Exalted said, bestowing favor upon His servants: "And He supplies you with wealth and children and makes for you gardens and makes for you rivers" and He (peace be upon him) said: "Poverty almost becomes disbelief"[14], and this is praise of wealth. And you will not stand upon the face of the combination after blame and praise except by knowing the wisdom of wealth, its purpose, its harms, and its dangers; until it becomes clear to you that it is good from one aspect and evil from another aspect, and that it is praiseworthy from where it is good and blameworthy from where it is evil, for it is not pure good nor pure evil, but rather it is a cause for both matters, and what has this description is inevitably praised at times and blamed at others, but the discerning distinguisher perceives that the praiseworthy from it is not the blameworthy, and its clarification is by seeking support from what we mentioned in the Book of Gratitude regarding the explanation of goods and the detailing of the degrees of blessings, and the sufficient amount in it is that the purpose of the wise and the people of insight is the happiness of the Hereafter which is the everlasting bliss and the kingdom and the abiding. And aiming for this is the habit of the noble and the wise, for it was said to the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him): Who are the most honorable of people and the wisest of them? He said: "The most frequent in remembrance (Dhikr) of death and the most prepared for it"[15]. And this happiness is not attained except through three means in the world: they are the spiritual virtues, like knowledge and good character, the bodily virtues: like health and safety, and the virtues external to the body: like wealth and other means. And the highest of them are the spiritual, then the bodily.

ğŸ“– Vol 4: Love, Longing, and Intimacy
And what he is capable of from himself and others, his capability is not from himself and by himself, but Allah is his Creator and the Creator of his capability and the Creator of his means and the Enabler for him of that. And if He were to unleash a mosquito upon the greatest king and strongest person of the animals, it would destroy him, so the servant has no capability except through the enabling of his Master, as He said regarding the greatest king of the earth, Dhul-Qarnayn, when He said: "Indeed, We enabled him in the earth." So all his kingdom and sovereignty were only through Allah the Exalted enabling him in a portion of the earth, and the entire earth is a speck of dust in comparison to the bodies of the universe, and all the dominions that people attain from the earth are a particle of that speck of dust, then that particle is also from the favor of Allah the Exalted and His enabling. Thus, it is impossible to love a servant from among the servants of Allah the Exalted for his capability, governance, enabling, dominion, and perfection of his strength and not love Allah the Exalted for that. And there is no power and no strength except with Allah the Most High, the Most Great. He is the Compeller, the Subduer, the All-Knowing, the All-Capable. The heavens are folded in His right hand, and the earth and its kingdom and what is upon it are in His grasp, and the forelocks of all creatures are in the grasp of His capability. If He were to destroy them from their last one, it would not diminish from His sovereignty and kingdom an atom. And if He were to create their like a thousand times, He would not be wearied by their creation, nor would fatigue or slackness touch Him in their invention. So there is no capability and no capable one except that he is an effect from the effects of His capability. So to Him belongs beauty, splendor, majesty, grandeur, subduing, and dominion. If it is conceivable to love a capable one for the perfection of his capability, then none deserves love for the perfection of capability except Him at all.

a.g: So he followed a way

Until, when he reached the setting of the sun, he found it [as if] setting in a spring of dark mud, and he found near it a people. Allah said, "O Dhul-Qarnayn, either you punish [them] or else adopt among them [a way of] goodness."
He said, "As for one who wrongs, we will punish him. Then he will be returned to his Lord, and He will punish him with a terrible punishment.
But as for one who believes and does righteousness, he will have a reward of Paradise, and we will speak to him from our command with ease."
Then he followed a way
Until, when he came to the rising of the sun, he found it rising on a people for whom We had not made against it any shield.
Thus. And We had encompassed [all] that he had in knowledge.
Then he followed a way
Until, when he reached [a pass] between two mountains, he found beside them a people who could hardly understand [his] speech.
They said, "O Dhul-Qarnayn, indeed Gog and Magog are [great] corrupters in the land. So may we assign for you an expenditure that you might make between us and them a barrier?"
He said, "That in which my Lord has established me is better [than what you offer], but assist me with strength; I will make between you and them a dam.

Bring me sheets of iron" - until, when he had leveled [them] between the two mountain walls, he said, "Blow [with bellows]," until when he had made it [like] fire, he said, "Bring me, that I may pour over it molten copper."
So Gog and Magog were unable to pass over it, nor were they able [to effect] in it any penetration.
[Dhul-Qarnayn] said, "This is a mercy from my Lord; but when the promise of my Lord comes, He will make it level, and ever is the promise of my Lord true."
And We will leave them that day surging over each other, and [then] the Horn will be blown, and We will assemble them in [one] assembly.
And We will present Hell that Day to the Disbelievers, on display -
Those whose eyes had been within a cover [removed] from My remembrance, and they were not able to hear.
Then do those who disbelieve think that they can take My servants instead of Me as allies? Indeed, We have prepared Hell for the disbelievers as a lodging.
Say, [O Muhammad], "Shall we [believers] inform you of the greatest losers as to [their] deeds?

ğŸ“– Vol 4: Fear and Hope
If it happens that his spirit (Ruh) departs in this peril before he becomes firm and returns to the foundation of faith (Iman), then he has been sealed with evil and his spirit has departed upon polytheism (Shirk) - we seek refuge in Allah from it. These are the ones intended by His saying, the Exalted: 'And there will appear to them from Allah that which they had not taken into account' and by His saying, the Mighty and Majestic: 'Say: Shall we inform you of the greatest losers in deeds? Those whose effort is lost in worldly life while they think that they are doing well in work.' And just as what will be in the future is unveiled in sleep due to the lightness of worldly occupations from the heart (Qalb), similarly some matters are unveiled in the throes of death, since the distractions of the world and the desires of the body are what prevent the heart from looking at the dominion (Malakut) to observe what is in the Preserved Tablet (Al-Lawh Al-Mahfuz) so that matters become unveiled to him as they truly are. Thus such a state becomes a cause for unveiling (Kashf), and the unveiling becomes a cause for doubt in the remaining beliefs.

ğŸ“– Vol 4: Watchfulness and Self-Examination
Rather, most people commit ignorance in what Allah the Exalted dislikes, and they think that they are doing good work. And do not think that the ignorant one who is capable of learning about it is excused - far from it! Rather, seeking knowledge is an obligation upon every Muslim. For this reason, two units of prayer from a knowledgeable person are better than a thousand units from a non-knowledgeable person, because he knows the defects of the souls (Nafs) and the plots of Satan (Shaytan) and the places of delusion, so he avoids that, and the ignorant one does not know it, so how can he guard against it? Thus, the ignorant one remains in hardship, and Satan (Shaytan) is in joy and gloating over him, so we seek refuge in Allah from ignorance and heedlessness, for it is the head of every misery and the foundation of every loss. So Allah the Exalted has decreed upon every servant that he should watch over his soul (Nafs) at his intention (Himmah) with action and his striving (Sa'y) with the limb, so he stops from the intention (Himmah) and from the striving (Sa'y) until it becomes clear to him through the light of knowledge that it is for Allah the Exalted, so he proceeds with it, or it is for the desire of the soul (Nafs), so he avoids it and restrains the heart (Qalb) from thinking about it and from intending (Himmah) it. For the first step in falsehood, if not repelled, produces desire, and desire produces intention (Himmah), and intention (Himmah) produces firm resolve, and resolve produces action, and action produces ruin and wrath. The eighth: Pride in erroneous opinion. Allah the Exalted said: "Is he whose evil deed is made fair-seeming unto him so that he sees it as good?" and He said: "And they think that they are doing good work." And the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) informed: that this will prevail over the latter part of this nation [101], and by this the past nations perished when they split into factions, each proud of his opinion, "and every party rejoices in what they have." Because the knower (Arif) is able to clarify to the ignorant (Jahil) his ignorance (Jahl) and remove it from him, except if he is proud of his opinion and his ignorance (Jahl), then he does not listen to the knower (Arif) and accuses him. Indeed, Allah has imposed upon him a calamity that destroys him while he thinks it a blessing, so how can his treatment be possible and how can he seek escape from what is the cause of his happiness in his belief? As for the term partnership (Shirkah) where it occurs, it is absolute for equality, and we have clarified that if the two intentions are equal, they cancel each other out, and there is neither for him nor against him, so one should not hope for reward upon it. Then indeed, the human being in partnership is always in danger, for he does not know which of the two matters is predominant in his intention; perhaps it will be a calamity upon him. And therefore, Allah the Exalted said: 'So whoever hopes for the meeting with his Lord, then let him do righteous work and not associate in the worship of his Lord anyone.' That is, do not hope for the meeting with the partnership whose best state is cancellation.
